lg.l: A courteous Wolfe to Romulus displaye
Her milky duggs, to Jove a Goat, tis sayd:
Nor is it strange to assert our mother Earth
Gave sucke to th' tender philosophicke birth;
If beasts soe small Heroes soe great could breed,
How great will hee be, whome the whose earth doth feed!

div.head: Discourse 2.
div.ab:
It is concluded by the peripaleticks, and orthodox philosophers, that the
thing nourishing is converted into the substance of the thing nourishes, and
assimilated to it, not indeed before; but after the alteration of it, and that is ac
counted an infallible axiome: for how would the thing nourishing (which is all
ready before the like: or how should those things, which, cannot be assimilated
to the thing nourished, be taken for nutriment, such as are wood, stones and
the like! as therefore the first is vayne, soe the other is contrary to nature, but
for an infant now borne to be nourished by the milke of animalls, is a thing
not repugnant to nature: because assimilation of it may be made, but far
more easily of the mothers, than of anothers: wherefore physicians doe con
clude, that it conduceth to the health, similitude of substance and manners,
as allso strength of an infant, if it be allways nourishes by the milke of its
owne mother, on the contrary if by another. This is the harmony of every
nature, that like delights in its like, and followes its footsteps, foe farre as it
is able, in all things, with a contains tacit consent and conspiration: the same
thing usually happens in the naturall worke of the philosophers, which is aequally
governed by nature in the conformation of it, as an infant in the mothers
wombe, and though a father and mother, and nurce Asecfebe by way of si
militude ascribed to it, yet it is not more artificiall, than the generation of
every animall: two seeds are by a certaine pleasant artifice joynd together
by animalls, and both humane sexes, which being united doe by successive
alteration produce an Embryo, which growes and is increased, acquires life
and motion, and then is nourished by milke: but nocessary it is for the wo
man in time of conception and impregnation to carry herselfe temperately
in heat, meat and drinke, motion and rest, and other circumstances, otherwise
an abortion will follow, and destruction of the conceived Embryo, which
observation in six things not naturall, because it is praescribed by physi
cians attending to their art, is allso artificiall. After the same manner if the
seeds be not joynes together in the philosophicall worke, they ought to be
joyned: but if they could be found somewhere joyned together, as the seed
of the Locke and Henne are had in an egge subsisting together in one
continent, then wouldthe philosophers worke be yet more naturalle, than
the generation of animalls. But let us grant, as the philosophers doe assert,
that one comes from the east and another from the west, and are made one,
what more is administred to them, than mixtiireonin their owne vessell, tem
perate heat and nutriment? the vessell is indeed artificiall, but herein is
noe differente, whether the nest be made by the Henne herselfe, or dispo
sed by a rustickecountry dame in envisome certaine place, as comon it is, the generation of
the eggs, and the hatching of chickens from them will be the same. Heat
is a naturall thing, whether it proceed from the temperate fire of fur
naces, and putrefaction of dung, or from the Sunne and aire, or bowells
of the mother, or elswhere: thus the Aegyptian doth by art administer
